title: IKEA Case Study: Strategy, Marketing, and Business Model
author: Sakshi Jonwal
license_note: Article content from Young Urban Project. Stored for dataset building; check source for citation and reuse rights.
content_paragraphs: IKEA built a durable global brand by marrying affordable design (flat-pack) with an immersive in-store experience and omnichannel digital presence. Their mission: 'To create a better everyday life for the many people.'

Key business model features: flat-pack design, DIY assembly, cost leadership through scale and efficient supply chains, omnichannel retail, and local market adaptation through country-specific catalogs and product lines.

Marketing highlights: consistent visual identity (blue & yellow), quirky but useful brand tone, collaborations (Virgil Abloh, Sonos, LEGO), content hubs (Ideas, Life at Home), AR experiences (IKEA Place), and sustainability programs including circular design and buy-back/refurbish efforts.
Operational strengths: localized sourcing, logistics automation, economies of scale, and a customer-centric culture with a loyalty program (IKEA Family).

sections.heading: Business Model
sections.text: Flat-pack + DIY assembly, efficient logistics, economies of scale, and global expansion with local adaptation.

sections.heading: Marketing Strategy
sections.text: Lifestyle positioning, consistent visual identity, content hubs, influencer/collab drops, and experiential in-store design.

sections.heading: Technology & Experience
sections.text: AR app, omnichannel UX, search and SEO for local discovery, and logistics automation.

key_takeaways: Design for operational efficiency (flat-pack) can be a major competitive advantage.
